summary.long: Ecclesiastes is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Vanity of vanities,” says the Preacher,
“Vanity of vanities! All is vanity.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What advantage does man have in all his work
Which he does under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A generation goes and a generation comes,
But the earth remains forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Also, the sun rises and the sun sets;
And hastening to its place it rises there again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Blowing toward the south,
Then turning toward the north,
The wind continues swirling along;
And on its circular courses the wind returns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the rivers flow into the sea,
Yet the sea is not full.
To the place where the rivers flow,
There they flow again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All things are wearisome;
Man is not able to tell it.
The eye is not satisfied with seeing,
Nor is the ear filled with hearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That which has been is that which will be,
And that which has been done is that which will be done.
So there is nothing new under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is there anything of which one might say,
“See this, it is new”?
Already it has existed for ages
Which were before us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is no remembrance of earlier things;
And also of the later things which will occur,
There will be for them no remembrance
Among those who will come later still.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, the Preacher, have been king over Israel in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I set my mind to seek and explore by wisdom concerning all that has been done under heaven. It is a grievous task which God has given to the sons of men to be afflicted with.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen all the works which have been done under the sun, and behold, all is vanity and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What is crooked cannot be straightened and what is lacking cannot be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself, “Behold, I have magnified and increased wisdom more than all who were over Jerusalem before me; and my mind has observed a wealth of wisdom and knowledge.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I set my mind to know wisdom and to know madness and folly; I realized that this also is striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because in much wisdom there is much grief, and increasing knowledge results in increasing pain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself, “Come now, I will test you with pleasure. So enjoy yourself.” And behold, it too was futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said of laughter, “It is madness,” and of pleasure, “What does it accomplish?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I explored with my mind how to stimulate my body with wine while my mind was guiding me wisely, and how to take hold of folly, until I could see what good there is for the sons of men to do under heaven the few years of their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I enlarged my works: I built houses for myself, I planted vineyards for myself;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made gardens and parks for myself and I planted in them all kinds of fruit trees;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made ponds of water for myself from which to irrigate a forest of growing trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I bought male and female slaves and I had homeborn slaves. Also I possessed flocks and herds larger than all who preceded me in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, I collected for myself silver and gold and the treasure of kings and provinces. I provided for myself male and female singers and the pleasures of men—many concubines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I became great and increased more than all who preceded me in Jerusalem. My wisdom also stood by me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All that my eyes desired I did not refuse them. I did not withhold my heart from any pleasure, for my heart was pleased because of all my labor and this was my reward for all my labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus I considered all my activities which my hands had done and the labor which I had exerted, and behold all was vanity and striving after wind and there was no profit under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I turned to consider wisdom, madness and folly; for what will the man do who will come after the king except what has already been done?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I saw that wisdom excels folly as light excels darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wise man’s eyes are in his head, but the fool walks in darkness. And yet I know that one fate befalls them both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I said to myself, “As is the fate of the fool, it will also befall me. Why then have I been extremely wise?” So I said to myself, “This too is vanity.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there is no lasting remembrance of the wise man as with the fool, inasmuch as in the coming days all will be forgotten. And how the wise man and the fool alike die!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I hated life, for the work which had been done under the sun was grievous to me; because everything is futility and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus I hated all the fruit of my labor for which I had labored under the sun, for I must leave it to the man who will come after me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And who knows whether he will be a wise man or a fool? Yet he will have control over all the fruit of my labor for which I have labored by acting wisely under the sun. This too is vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore I completely despaired of all the fruit of my labor for which I had labored under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When there is a man who has labored with wisdom, knowledge and skill, then he gives his legacy to one who has not labored with them. This too is vanity and a great evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For what does a man get in all his labor and in his striving with which he labors under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because all his days his task is painful and grievous; even at night his mind does not rest. This too is vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is nothing better for a man than to eat and drink and tell himself that his labor is good. This also I have seen that it is from the hand of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For who can eat and who can have enjoyment without Him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For to a person who is good in His sight He has given wisdom and knowledge and joy, while to the sinner He has given the task of gathering and collecting so that he may give to one who is good in God’s sight. This too is vanity and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is an appointed time for everything. And there is a time for every event under heaven—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to give birth and a time to die;
A time to plant and a time to uproot what is planted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to kill and a time to heal;
A time to tear down and a time to build up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to weep and a time to laugh;
A time to mourn and a time to dance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to throw stones and a time to gather stones;
A time to embrace and a time to shun embracing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to search and a time to give up as lost;
A time to keep and a time to throw away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to tear apart and a time to sew together;
A time to be silent and a time to speak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to love and a time to hate;
A time for war and a time for peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What profit is there to the worker from that in which he toils?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen the task which God has given the sons of men with which to occupy themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has made everything appropriate in its time. He has also set eternity in their heart, yet so that man will not find out the work which God has done from the beginning even to the end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that there is nothing better for them than to rejoice and to do good in one’s lifetime;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: moreover, that every man who eats and drinks sees good in all his labor—it is the gift of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that everything God does will remain forever; there is nothing to add to it and there is nothing to take from it, for God has so worked that men should fear Him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That which is has been already and that which will be has already been, for God seeks what has passed by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, I have seen under the sun that in the place of justice there is wickedness and in the place of righteousness there is wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself, “God will judge both the righteous man and the wicked man,” for a time for every matter and for every deed is there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself concerning the sons of men, “God has surely tested them in order for them to see that they are but beasts.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the fate of the sons of men and the fate of beasts is the same. As one dies so dies the other; indeed, they all have the same breath and there is no advantage for man over beast, for all is vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All go to the same place. All came from the dust and all return to the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who knows that the breath of man ascends upward and the breath of the beast descends downward to the earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen that nothing is better than that man should be happy in his activities, for that is his lot. For who will bring him to see what will occur after him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I looked again at all the acts of oppression which were being done under the sun. And behold I saw the tears of the oppressed and that they had no one to comfort them; and on the side of their oppressors was power, but they had no one to comfort them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I congratulated the dead who are already dead more than the living who are still living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But better off than both of them is the one who has never existed, who has never seen the evil activity that is done under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen that every labor and every skill which is done is the result of rivalry between a man and his neighbor. This too is vanity and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fool folds his hands and consumes his own flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One hand full of rest is better than two fists full of labor and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I looked again at vanity under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a certain man without a dependent, having neither a son nor a brother, yet there was no end to all his labor. Indeed, his eyes were not satisfied with riches and he never asked, “And for whom am I laboring and depriving myself of pleasure?” This too is vanity and it is a grievous task.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two are better than one because they have a good return for their labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For if either of them falls, the one will lift up his companion. But woe to the one who falls when there is not another to lift him up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, if two lie down together they keep warm, but how can one be warm alone?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if one can overpower him who is alone, two can resist him. A cord of three strands is not quickly torn apart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A poor yet wise lad is better than an old and foolish king who no longer knows how to receive instruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he has come out of prison to become king, even though he was born poor in his kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen all the living under the sun throng to the side of the second lad who replaces him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is no end to all the people, to all who were before them, and even the ones who will come later will not be happy with him, for this too is vanity and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Guard your steps as you go to the house of God and draw near to listen rather than to offer the sacrifice of fools; for they do not know they are doing evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be hasty in word or impulsive in thought to bring up a matter in the presence of God. For God is in heaven and you are on the earth; therefore let your words be few.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the dream comes through much effort and the voice of a fool through many words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you make a vow to God, do not be late in paying it; for He takes no delight in fools. Pay what you vow!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is better that you should not vow than that you should vow and not pay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not let your speech cause you to sin and do not say in the presence of the messenger of God that it was a mistake. Why should God be angry on account of your voice and destroy the work of your hands?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For in many dreams and in many words there is emptiness. Rather, fear God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you see oppression of the poor and denial of justice and righteousness in the province, do not be shocked at the sight; for one official watches over another official, and there are higher officials over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all, a king who cultivates the field is an advantage to the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He who loves money will not be satisfied with money, nor he who loves abundance with its income. This too is vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When good things increase, those who consume them increase. So what is the advantage to their owners except to look on?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sleep of the working man is pleasant, whether he eats little or much; but the full stomach of the rich man does not allow him to sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is a grievous evil which I have seen under the sun: riches being hoarded by their owner to his hurt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When those riches were lost through a bad investment and he had fathered a son, then there was nothing to support him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he had come naked from his mother’s womb, so will he return as he came. He will take nothing from the fruit of his labor that he can carry in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This also is a grievous evil—exactly as a man is born, thus will he die. So what is the advantage to him who toils for the wind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Throughout his life he also eats in darkness with great vexation, sickness and anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here is what I have seen to be good and fitting: to eat, to drink and enjoy oneself in all one’s labor in which he toils under the sun during the few years of his life which God has given him; for this is his reward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, as for every man to whom God has given riches and wealth, He has also empowered him to eat from them and to receive his reward and rejoice in his labor; this is the gift of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he will not often consider the years of his life, because God keeps him occupied with the gladness of his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is an evil which I have seen under the sun and it is prevalent among men—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a man to whom God has given riches and wealth and honor so that his soul lacks nothing of all that he desires; yet God has not empowered him to eat from them, for a foreigner enjoys them. This is vanity and a severe affliction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man fathers a hundred children and lives many years, however many they be, but his soul is not satisfied with good things and he does not even have a proper burial, then I say, “Better the miscarriage than he,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for it comes in futility and goes into obscurity; and its name is covered in obscurity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It never sees the sun and it never knows anything; it is better off than he.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if the other man lives a thousand years twice and does not enjoy good things—do not all go to one place?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All a man’s labor is for his mouth and yet the appetite is not satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For what advantage does the wise man have over the fool? What advantage does the poor man have, knowing how to walk before the living?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What the eyes see is better than what the soul desires. This too is futility and a striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever exists has already been named, and it is known what man is; for he cannot dispute with him who is stronger than he is.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there are many words which increase futility. What then is the advantage to a man?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For who knows what is good for a man during his lifetime, during the few years of his futile life? He will spend them like a shadow. For who can tell a man what will be after him under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A good name is better than a good ointment,
And the day of one’s death is better than the day of one’s birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is better to go to a house of mourning
Than to go to a house of feasting,
Because that is the end of every man,
And the living takes it to heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sorrow is better than laughter,
For when a face is sad a heart may be happy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The mind of the wise is in the house of mourning,
While the mind of fools is in the house of pleasure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is better to listen to the rebuke of a wise man
Than for one to listen to the song of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For oppression makes a wise man mad,
And a bribe corrupts the heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The end of a matter is better than its beginning;
Patience of spirit is better than haughtiness of spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be eager in your heart to be angry,
For anger resides in the bosom of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not say, “Why is it that the former days were better than these?”
For it is not from wisdom that you ask about this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom along with an inheritance is good
And an advantage to those who see the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For wisdom is protection just as money is protection,
But the advantage of knowledge is that wisdom preserves the lives of its possessors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Consider the work of God,
For who is able to straighten what He has bent?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the day of prosperity be happy,
But in the day of adversity consider—
God has made the one as well as the other
So that man will not discover anything that will be after him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen everything during my lifetime of futility; there is a righteous man who perishes in his righteousness and there is a wicked man who prolongs his life in his wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be excessively righteous and do not be overly wise. Why should you ruin yourself?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be excessively wicked and do not be a fool. Why should you die before your time?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is good that you grasp one thing and also not let go of the other; for the one who fears God comes forth with both of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wisdom strengthens a wise man more than ten rulers who are in a city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, there is not a righteous man on earth who continually does good and who never sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, do not take seriously all words which are spoken, so that you will not hear your servant cursing you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you also have realized that you likewise have many times cursed others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I tested all this with wisdom, and I said, “I will be wise,” but it was far from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What has been is remote and exceedingly mysterious. Who can discover it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I directed my mind to know, to investigate and to seek wisdom and an explanation, and to know the evil of folly and the foolishness of madness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I discovered more bitter than death the woman whose heart is snares and nets, whose hands are chains. One who is pleasing to God will escape from her, but the sinner will be captured by her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Behold, I have discovered this,” says the Preacher, “adding one thing to another to find an explanation,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: which I am still seeking but have not found. I have found one man among a thousand, but I have not found a woman among all these.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold, I have found only this, that God made men upright, but they have sought out many devices.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is like the wise man and who knows the interpretation of a matter? A man’s wisdom illumines him and causes his stern face to beam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I say, “Keep the command of the king because of the oath before God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be in a hurry to leave him. Do not join in an evil matter, for he will do whatever he pleases.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since the word of the king is authoritative, who will say to him, “What are you doing?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He who keeps a royal command experiences no trouble, for a wise heart knows the proper time and procedure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there is a proper time and procedure for every delight, though a man’s trouble is heavy upon him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If no one knows what will happen, who can tell him when it will happen?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No man has authority to restrain the wind with the wind, or authority over the day of death; and there is no discharge in the time of war, and evil will not deliver those who practice it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All this I have seen and applied my mind to every deed that has been done under the sun wherein a man has exercised authority over another man to his hurt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, I have seen the wicked buried, those who used to go in and out from the holy place, and they are soon forgotten in the city where they did thus. This too is futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because the sentence against an evil deed is not executed quickly, therefore the hearts of the sons of men among them are given fully to do evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although a sinner does evil a hundred times and may lengthen his life, still I know that it will be well for those who fear God, who fear Him openly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But it will not be well for the evil man and he will not lengthen his days like a shadow, because he does not fear God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is futility which is done on the earth, that is, there are righteous men to whom it happens according to the deeds of the wicked. On the other hand, there are evil men to whom it happens according to the deeds of the righteous. I say that this too is futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I commended pleasure, for there is nothing good for a man under the sun except to eat and to drink and to be merry, and this will stand by him in his toils throughout the days of his life which God has given him under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I gave my heart to know wisdom and to see the task which has been done on the earth (even though one should never sleep day or night),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I saw every work of God, I concluded that man cannot discover the work which has been done under the sun. Even though man should seek laboriously, he will not discover; and though the wise man should say, “I know,” he cannot discover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have taken all this to my heart and explain it that righteous men, wise men, and their deeds are in the hand of God. Man does not know whether it will be love or hatred; anything awaits him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is the same for all. There is one fate for the righteous and for the wicked; for the good, for the clean and for the unclean; for the man who offers a sacrifice and for the one who does not sacrifice. As the good man is, so is the sinner; as the swearer is, so is the one who is afraid to swear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is an evil in all that is done under the sun, that there is one fate for all men. Furthermore, the hearts of the sons of men are full of evil and insanity is in their hearts throughout their lives. Afterwards they go to the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For whoever is joined with all the living, there is hope; surely a live dog is better than a dead lion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the living know they will die; but the dead do not know anything, nor have they any longer a reward, for their memory is forgotten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed their love, their hate and their zeal have already perished, and they will no longer have a share in all that is done under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go then, eat your bread in happiness and drink your wine with a cheerful heart; for God has already approved your works.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let your clothes be white all the time, and let not oil be lacking on your head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Enjoy life with the woman whom you love all the days of your fleeting life which He has given to you under the sun; for this is your reward in life and in your toil in which you have labored under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with all your might; for there is no activity or planning or knowledge or wisdom in Sheol where you are going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I again saw under the sun that the race is not to the swift and the battle is not to the warriors, and neither is bread to the wise nor wealth to the discerning nor favor to men of ability; for time and chance overtake them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, man does not know his time: like fish caught in a treacherous net and birds trapped in a snare, so the sons of men are ensnared at an evil time when it suddenly falls on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also this I came to see as wisdom under the sun, and it impressed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a small city with few men in it and a great king came to it, surrounded it and constructed large siegeworks against it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But there was found in it a poor wise man and he delivered the city by his wisdom. Yet no one remembered that poor man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I said, “Wisdom is better than strength.” But the wisdom of the poor man is despised and his words are not heeded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of the wise heard in quietness are better than the shouting of a ruler among fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wisdom is better than weapons of war, but one sinner destroys much good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dead flies make a perfumer’s oil stink, so a little foolishness is weightier than wisdom and honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A wise man’s heart directs him toward the right, but the foolish man’s heart directs him toward the left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even when the fool walks along the road, his sense is lacking and he demonstrates to everyone that he is a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the ruler’s temper rises against you, do not abandon your position, because composure allays great offenses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is an evil I have seen under the sun, like an error which goes forth from the ruler—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: folly is set in many exalted places while rich men sit in humble places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen slaves riding on horses and princes walking like slaves on the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He who digs a pit may fall into it, and a serpent may bite him who breaks through a wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He who quarries stones may be hurt by them, and he who splits logs may be endangered by them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the axe is dull and he does not sharpen its edge, then he must exert more strength. Wisdom has the advantage of giving success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the serpent bites before being charmed, there is no profit for the charmer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Words from the mouth of a wise man are gracious, while the lips of a fool consume him;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the beginning of his talking is folly and the end of it is wicked madness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet the fool multiplies words. No man knows what will happen, and who can tell him what will come after him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The toil of a fool so wearies him that he does not even know how to go to a city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Woe to you, O land, whose king is a lad and whose princes feast in the morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Blessed are you, O land, whose king is of nobility and whose princes eat at the appropriate time—for strength and not for drunkenness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Through indolence the rafters sag, and through slackness the house leaks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Men prepare a meal for enjoyment, and wine makes life merry, and money is the answer to everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, in your bedchamber do not curse a king, and in your sleeping rooms do not curse a rich man, for a bird of the heavens will carry the sound and the winged creature will make the matter known.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cast your bread on the surface of the waters, for you will find it after many days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Divide your portion to seven, or even to eight, for you do not know what misfortune may occur on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the clouds are full, they pour out rain upon the earth; and whether a tree falls toward the south or toward the north, wherever the tree falls, there it lies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He who watches the wind will not sow and he who looks at the clouds will not reap.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as you do not know the path of the wind and how bones are formed in the womb of the pregnant woman, so you do not know the activity of God who makes all things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sow your seed in the morning and do not be idle in the evening, for you do not know whether morning or evening sowing will succeed, or whether both of them alike will be good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The light is pleasant, and it is good for the eyes to see the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, if a man should live many years, let him rejoice in them all, and let him remember the days of darkness, for they will be many. Everything that is to come will be futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rejoice, young man, during your childhood, and let your heart be pleasant during the days of young manhood. And follow the impulses of your heart and the desires of your eyes. Yet know that God will bring you to judgment for all these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So, remove grief and anger from your heart and put away pain from your body, because childhood and the prime of life are fleeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember also your Creator in the days of your youth, before the evil days come and the years draw near when you will say, “I have no delight in them”;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: before the sun and the light, the moon and the stars are darkened, and clouds return after the rain;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in the day that the watchmen of the house tremble, and mighty men stoop, the grinding ones stand idle because they are few, and those who look through windows grow dim;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the doors on the street are shut as the sound of the grinding mill is low, and one will arise at the sound of the bird, and all the daughters of song will sing softly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, men are afraid of a high place and of terrors on the road; the almond tree blossoms, the grasshopper drags himself along, and the caperberry is ineffective. For man goes to his eternal home while mourners go about in the street.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember Him before the silver cord is broken and the golden bowl is crushed, the pitcher by the well is shattered and the wheel at the cistern is crushed;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then the dust will return to the earth as it was, and the spirit will return to God who gave it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Vanity of vanities,” says the Preacher, “all is vanity!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition to being a wise man, the Preacher also taught the people knowledge; and he pondered, searched out and arranged many proverbs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Preacher sought to find delightful words and to write words of truth correctly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of wise men are like goads, and masters of these collections are like well-driven nails; they are given by one Shepherd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But beyond this, my son, be warned: the writing of many books is endless, and excessive devotion to books is wearying to the body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The conclusion, when all has been heard, is: fear God and keep His commandments, because this applies to every person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For God will bring every act to judgment, everything which is hidden, whether it is good or evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator
